Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit

1023.96875
0.03125 Nm
Torque offset for considering that torque request is passive

Torque offset for considering that driver request is completely limited by vehicle speed limiter

Logical constant to disable driver request passive detection

Simulate cruise control is requesting engine torque if combustion engine torque setpoint is higher than idles speed for hybrid
� General Information
Adaptation PTQM Aggregate to Audi Object Code
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at reset:
LV_CT = 0;
FAC_TQ_REQ = 0;
LV_TQ_CRU_ACT = 0;
LV_DRIV_PAS_VS_LIM = 0;
TQ_OFS_INER_PT = 0;
LV_INTV_CRU_CUS = 0;
LV_INTV_VSL_CUS = 0;
TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ_CUS = -1024 Nm
LV_DRIV_PAS_TQ = 0
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10 ms; mandatory to calculate after the PTQM aggregate calculations
� Function Description
/* Calculations independent of Powertrain type*/
TQ_OFS_INER_PT = TQ_INER_SUM_CAN_CUS;
N_GRD_PT = N_GRD_PT_CUS;
/* Selection of speci?c calculations for hybrid and combustion engine based Powertrain types*/
if LV_VAR_HYB==1
then
#if ( NC_PT_TYP bitwise AND NC_PT_TYP_HYB)
then COMPILE AND EXECUTE SUB-SECTION 1.2
else
/*do nothing*/
#endif
else
#if (NC_PT_TYP bitwise AND NC_PT_TYP_CMB_ENG)
File: AE302001.00I
23916Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without

PTQM, AGGR adaptation: PTQM
then
COMPILE AND EXECUTE SUB-SECTION 1.1
else
/*do nothing*/
#endif
endif
63.1.1 Adaption for PTQM for vehicles with only combustion engine
LV_TQ_CRU_ACT = LV_INTV_CRU;
if TQ_VS_MAX <TQ_MIN_CLU + C_TQ_OFS_DRIV_PAS_VS_LIM
then LV_DRIV_PAS_VS_LIM=1
endif
if TQ_VS_MAX >TQ_MIN_CLU + C_TQ_HYS_DRIV_PAS_VS_LIM
then LV_DRIV_PAS_VS_LIM=0
endif
/*If drive-off controller is active, fuel cut-off must not be activated*/
if LV_DROF==1 AND LC_CT_DROF_INH==1
then LV_CT = 0
else LV_CT = (LV_DRIV_PASOR LV_DRIV_PAS_VS_LIM)
endif
if (TQ_MAX_CLU-TQ_MIN_CLU) = 0
then FAC_TQ_REQ = 0
else FAC_TQ_REQ = (TQ_REQ_CLU - TQ_MIN_CLU) / (TQ_MAX_CLU - TQ_MIN_CLU);
endif
63.1.2 Adaption for PTQM for hybrid vehicles
/* Information provided about torque passive can be modi?ed by checking the requested torque for combus-
tion engine*/
if TQ_ENG_PTQ_REQ_FAST< TQ_MIN_CLU + C_TQ_OFS_DRIV_PAS_TQ
then LV_DRIV_PAS_TQ=1;
endif
if TQ_ENG_PTQ_REQ_FAST> TQ_MIN_CLU + C_TQ_HYS_DRIV_PAS_TQ
then LV_DRIV_PAS_TQ=0;
endif
/*If drive-off controller is active, fuel cut-off must not be activated*/
if LV_DROF==1 AND LC_CT_DROF_INH==1
then LV_CT = 0
else LV_CT = (LV_DRIV_PASOR LV_DRIV_PAS_TQ)
endif
if (TQ_ENG_MAX <= TQ_MIN_CLU)
then FAC_TQ_REQ = 0
else FAC_TQ_REQ = (TQ_ENG_PTQ_REQ_FAST-TQ_MIN_CLU)/
/(TQ_ENG_MAX- TQ_MIN_CLU);

Hysteresis on relative threshold for driver passive detection
� General Information
In this context ?driver request? stands for the coordinated driver torque request from pedal and the cruise
control torque request.
Passive driver means then that this coordinated torque request is close to the minimum available torque.
In case of electronic throttle deactivation all torque requests can only be realized by spark advance interaction
or single cylinder cut off coordination. For this purpose the driver passive detection is deactivated (LV_DRIV_
PAS = 0).
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 10MS

63.2.2 Operation mode
Selection of operation mode:
- For hybrid vehicles, the driver request passive information is delivered by a customer provided function
- For standard vehicles, the driver request passive information is calculated internally
63.2.2.1 Compiler switch for hybrid and non-hybrid based systems
Some functionalities are calculated in a different way depending on the power train con?guration: hybrid or
nor hybrid (only combustion).
63.2.2.2 Customer provided calculation of driver passive indication
[#NC_PT_TYP == Hybrid]
In case of hybrid vehicles, the driver request passive information is provided by a customer functionality. So
the outputs are mapped to customer variables

Effective engine torque at clutch
IP_CRLC_N_GRD_H_RES_RNG_TQE - 0... FFFFH 0...
0.999984741211
15.2588e-6 -
LDP_N_GRD_IP_CRLC_N_GRD_H_RES 8 0... FFFFH -32768 ...32767 1 rpm/s
Filter Coef?cient for low pass ?ltering of N_GRD_H_RES_RNG
� General Information
This function calculates the actual torque at clutch of the whole powertrain based on actual engine torque and
actual torque losses from auxiliaries. This value TQ_AV is the actual static effective torque at clutch. TQE is the
actual effective torque at clutch inclusive inertia.
These values are used for external units (e.g. traction control and gear box) as a feedback signal.
The dynamic torque is derived as follows:
TQE_DIF = J (kg*m?2) * dw/dt (1/s?2)
TQE_DIF = J (kg*m?2) * pi/30 * N_GRD (1/min/s)
TQE_DIF = C_FAC_TQE (kg*m?2*min) * N_GRD (1/min/s)
C_FAC_TQE = J (kg*m?2) *pi/30
� Application Conditions

PTQM, Powertrain driver torque request coordination
63.5 Powertrain driver torque request coordination
� Data De?nition
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
LV_INTV_CRU O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Boolean signals intervention of cruise control (CRU demand is equal or greater than driver demand)
LV_INTV_VSL O/V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Boolean signals intervention of vehicle speed limiter (VSL demand is less than driver demand)
TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ O/V 8000... 7FFFH -1024...
1023.96875
0.03125 Nm
Coordinated driver torque request from pedal and cruise control
TQ_REQ_CLU O/V 8000... 7FFFH -1024...
1023.96875
0.03125 Nm
Requested torque at clutch by real and virtual drivers
� Input Data
LV_ACT_CRU
{p. 26414}
LV_ACT_VSL
{p. 23176}
LV_INTV_CRU_CUS
{p. 23915}
LV_INTV_VSL_CUS
{p. 23915}
LV_VAR_HYB
{p. 23190}
NC_PT_TYP
{p. 24719}

{p. 24719}

{p. 24719}
TQ_CRU_REQ
{p. 26415}
TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ_CUS
{p. 23915}
TQ_DRIV_REQ
{p. 4825}

{p. 25176}
TQ_REQ_CLU_CUS
{p. 3387}
TQ_VS_MAX
{p. 26422}
TQ_VSL_REQ
{p. 26422}
� General Information
Not only can the driver provide a torque request via accelerator pedal but also the cruise control or the vehicle
speed limiter (variable or static limitation). Coordination is necessary as all torque requests can request a
torque demand simultaneously.
As the driver has a higher priority than the cruise control, driver torque request and cruise control torque
request are coordinated by a maximum selection with the output TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ. The intervention of the
cruise control is indicated by LV_INTV_CRU. The coordination between the cruise control and the driver is only
done if the cruise control is active (LV_ACT_CRU = 1).
As the vehicle speed limiter has a higher priority than the driver or the cruise control, the TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ
and torque request from vehicle speed limiter are coordinated by a minimum selection. The intervention of the
speed limiter is indicated by the boolean LV_INTV_VSL. The coordination between the driver (cruise control)
and the vehicle speed limiter is only done if the limiter is active (LV_ACT_VSL = 1).
Highest priority of driver torque request is given to the static vehicle speed limitation with a min selection.

Deactivation: never

## Function
The Simulink diagram describes a function block `PTQM`, which stands for Passive Torque Management. It is designed to detect the driver's passive torque request. It handles both hybrid and non-hybrid vehicles, with potentially different calculation methods based on the vehicle type.

## Inputs

*   **Initialization Inputs:** `<fc_INI>` -  Presumably a boolean signal used for initialization.
*   **Torque Inputs:**
    *   `<TQ_MAX_CLU>` -  Maximum Clutch Torque.
    *   `<TQ_MIN_CLU>` -  Minimum Clutch Torque.
    *   `<TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ>` - Driver Cruise Request Torque.
*   **Vehicle State Inputs:**
    *   `<LV_MTC_CUR_OFF>` -  Engine Off State.
    *   `<N_SP_IS_RATIO>` -  Speed Ratio.
*   **Configuration Inputs:**
    *   `APP_CDN` - Application specific constant definition.
    *   `<NC_PT_TYP>` -  Powertrain Type (e.g., ICE or Hybrid).
    *   `<LV_VAR_HYB>` -  Hybrid Variant.
    *   `<NC_PT_TYP_HYB>` -  Powertrain Type Hybrid.
    *   `<NC_PT_TYP_CMB_ENG>` - Powertrain Type Combustion Engine.
    *   `<LV_DRIV_PAS_CUS>` - Driver Passive Torque Customer provided, used when `NC_PT_TYP == Hybrid`

## Outputs

*   `<LV_DRIV_PAS>` -  Level of Driver Passive Torque. This is the primary output of the function.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Initialization:** Upon system reset (indicated by `RST` and triggered by the `<fc_INI>` signal), the system initializes. The diagram 63.2.2 shows the `<LV_DRIV_PAS>` initialized to 0.
2.  **Recurrence:** The diagram executes every 10ms.
3.  **Activation/Deactivation:** The block is activated "always", but deactivated if `<fc_OPM_10MS>` is not true.
4.  **Input Processing:** The input signals listed above are fed into the `CALCULATION` block. The inputs are fed into the Calculation Block denoted as Inp.
5.  **Calculation:**  Inside the `CALCULATION` block, the inputs are processed. The specific calculation logic isn't detailed in the block diagram, but it likely involves applying gains, limits, and potentially some state logic based on the vehicle type and other input conditions.
6.  **Output Generation:** The `CALCULATION` block generates the `<LV_DRIV_PAS>` output which represents the driver's passive torque request level. This is outputted to the block `<LV DRIV PAS>`.
7.  **Hybrid Vehicle Handling:**  The text indicates that for hybrid vehicles (determined by `NC_PT_TYP` being equal to "Hybrid"), the `<LV_DRIV_PAS>` value is provided by the customer. This means that the `CALCULATION` block potentially selects between internal calculations (for non-hybrid vehicles) or directly passes through the customer provided `<LV_DRIV_PAS_CUS>` signal. This is not explicitly shown in the block diagram itself.

2.  **Activation/Deactivation:** The system is always active. If not true then deactivation flag will be true.

3.

*   `<TQ_AV>`: Torque Average.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Initialization:** The system is initialized when the `fc_INI` input is active (RST).

2.  **Activation/Deactivation:** The system is always active. If not true then deactivation flag will be true.

3.  **Input Processing:**
    *   Multiple torque-related inputs (`<TQ_LOSS_ADD>`, `<TQ_ENG>`, `<N_GRD>`) and the high-resolution ground speed range (`<N_GRD_H_RES_RNG>`) are fed into the system.

4.  **Feedback Loop:** There is a feedback loop around the `fc()` function block from the output of "N_GRD_H_RES_RNG_FIL" block. The output named opm comes from this block and gets inputed in the function fc()

5.  **Filtering:** The ground speed range signal (`<N_GRD_H_RES_RNG>`) is filtered by the "N_GRD_H_RES_RNG_FIL" block.

6.  **Output Generation:** The system generates various torque-related outputs (`<TQE>`, `<TQE_DIF>`, `<TQE_DIF_H_RNG>`, `<TQ_AV>`), along with the filtered ground speed range signal (`N_GRD_H_RES_RNG_FIL`).

In summary, the system takes torque-related inputs, a high-resolution ground speed range, applies filtering and other processing, and produces filtered torque and related signals. The `fc()` block likely contains the core logic for calculating the torque estimates and differences, potentially incorporating the feedback signal.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and output total torque losses (TQ_LOSS) and additional torque losses (TQ_LOSS_ADD) based on several input torque loss components and a conditioning logic. The function is part of a powertrain torque management system.

## Inputs

The key inputs to the system are:

*   **TQ_LOSS_ENG:** Engine torque losses.
*   **TQ_LOSS_ALTER:** Torque loss component.
*   **TQ_LOSS_ACC:** Torque loss component.
*   **TQ_LOSS_PSTE:** Torque loss component.
*   **APP_CDN (V.7.2):** A flag/signal from another application.
*   **RST:** Reset Signal.

## Outputs

The system has two main outputs:

*   **TQ_LOSS:** Total torque losses.
*   **TQ_LOSS_ADD:** Additional torque losses.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Initialization:** The system initializes to a reset (RST) state. This occurs upon startup. This is triggered every 10ms by fc_INI signal.

2.  **Conditional Logic:** A Function-Call subsystem named "INI" is called to initialize the system to reset state.

3.  **Input Summation:** The four torque loss inputs (TQ_LOSS_ENG, TQ_LOSS_ALTER, TQ_LOSS_ACC, TQ_LOSS_PSTE) are fed into the function-call subsystem labelled as <input>.

4.  **Conditional Operation (OPM):** Based on the APP_CDN signal and the initilization state (fc_INI, fc_OPM), the subsystem "OPM" performs calculation on the sum of the torque loss values.

5.  **Output:** The subsystem labelled as "OPM" generates the two outputs, TQ_LOSS (Total Torque Losses) and TQ_LOSS_ADD (Additional Torque Losses), based on the internal calculations. The outputs are then available for use by other parts of the powertrain torque management system.

In essence, the diagram calculates a sum of torque loss components and outputs the result, while also providing an "additional" torque loss value. The diagram includes initialisation logic and is configured to run every 10ms. The conditional logic surrounding the OPM block likely determines which calculation is performed.

## Function

The Simulink diagrams illustrate the calculation of total torque losses in a powertrain system, likely within an engine control unit (ECU). It shows two operating modes: initialization (reset) and normal operation.  The normal operation mode focuses on the coordination/summation of individual torque loss contributions.

## Inputs

*   **Initialization at Reset:**
    *   Implicit: Reset signal (triggers the initialization).

*   **Operation Mode:**
    *   `TQ_LOSS_ENG`: Torque loss from the engine.
    *   `TQ_LOSS_ALTER`: Torque loss from the alternator.
    *   `TQ_LOSS_ACC`: Torque loss from accessories.
    *   `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`:  Torque loss from power steering.

## Outputs

*   `TQ_LOSS_ADD`:  Additional or adjusted torque loss (intermediate or final).
*   `TQ_LOSS`: Total torque loss.
*   `fc`: Function of the initialization (reset)

## Logic Flow

**1. Initialization at Reset (Figure 63.4.2):**

*   This section represents the system's state upon reset.
*   `TQ_LOSS_ADD` is initialized to a value of 1.
*   `TQ_LOSS` is initialized to a value of 2.
*   The output of the initialization is passed into the function `f(x)` = `fc`.

**2. Operation Mode - Coordination of Additional Torque Losses (Figure 63.4.3):**

*   The four input torque loss signals (`TQ_LOSS_ENG`, `TQ_LOSS_ALTER`, `TQ_LOSS_ACC`, `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`) are summed.
*   `TQ_LOSS_ENG` and `TQ_LOSS_ALTER` are added first.
*   The result is then added to `TQ_LOSS_ACC`.
*   Finally, the result is added to `TQ_LOSS_PSTE`.
*   The intermediate sum is labelled as `TQ_LOSS_ADD`.
*   `TQ_LOSS_ADD` and `TQ_LOSS_ADD` are used as the outputs of the block.

In summary, the system calculates the total torque loss by summing various individual torque loss components. The initialization sets initial values, and the operation mode performs the continuous calculation of total torque loss during normal engine operation. The specific mathematical meaning of the initialization values (1 and 2) is not clear from the diagram alone and would require further context.

## Function

The Simulink diagram represents a Powertrain Driver Torque Request Coordination module (PTQM). Its primary function is to coordinate and manage torque requests from different sources (cruise control and driver) and limit them based on vehicle speed and operating conditions.  The module calculates intervention levels for both cruise control and vehicle speed limiting, and then combines maximum and minimum torque requests to obtain a final torque request value.

## Inputs

*   `TQ_CRU_REQ`: Cruise control torque request.
*   `TQ_DRIV_REQ`: Driver torque request.
*   `LV_ACT_CRU`: Active cruise control intervention level.
*   `TQ_VSL_REQ`: Vehicle speed limiting torque request.
*   `LV_ACT_VSL`: Active vehicle speed limiting intervention level.
*   `TQ_VS_MAX`: Maximum torque allowed by the vehicle speed limiter.
*   `TQ_MIN_CLU`: Minimum torque allowed by the clutch (likely based on clutch position or state).

## Outputs

*   `TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ`:  Torque request for cruise control that's limited.
*   `LV_INTV_CRU`: Cruise control intervention level that is limited.
*   `LV_INTV_VSL`: Vehicle speed limiting intervention level that is limited.
*   `TQ_REQ_CLU`: Final, combined torque request considering all inputs and limitations.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Cruise Control Torque Request Handling:**
    *   `TQ_CRU_REQ` and `TQ_DRIV_REQ` are fed into a "max" block.  This selects the larger of the two values.
    *   The output of the max block is limited by the `LV_ACT_CRU` signal through a subtract block. The signal `LV_ACT_CRU` is likely a value subtracted from the `TQ_CRU_REQ + TQ_DRIV_REQ (max)` signal.
    *   The subtracted/limited cruise control torque request is output as `LV_INTV_CRU`.
    *   This signal is then limited again. When it is not close to 0, the block passes through cruise control torque, `TQ_CRU_REQ` and `TQ_DRIV_REQ`.
    *   The final value is then given as output `TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ`

2.  **Vehicle Speed Limiting Torque Request Handling:**
    *   `TQ_VSL_REQ` is fed into a "min" block.  This selects the smaller of the two values. This value is then limited again.
    *   The output of the min block is limited by the `LV_ACT_VSL` signal through a subtract block. The signal `LV_ACT_VSL` is likely a value subtracted from the `TQ_VSL_REQ` signal.
    *   The subtracted/limited vehicle speed limiting torque request is output as `LV_INTV_VSL`.
    *   This signal is then limited again. When it is not close to 0, the block passes through vehicle speed limiting torque, `TQ_VSL_REQ`.

3.  **Final Torque Request Combination:**
    *   `TQ_VS_MAX` and `TQ_MIN_CLU` are fed into a "min" block. This selects the smaller of the two values.
    *   The final limited `TQ_DRIV_CRU_REQ` and `LV_INTV_VSL` are fed into a "max" block. This selects the larger of the two values. The output is `TQ_REQ_CLU`
